comments.commentBody: *Spring* for one or even for two. I own 3!
Used a large skillet to great success. Just keep it covered and turn chicken pieces several times to distribute sauce. I needed to add a bit of water.

Absolutely delicious!! My husband and son cooked these tonight ( lucky lady) - I was a little wary of using cilantro ( instead of coleslaw) as the green addition, but it was great.
Chicken was spicy and wonderful.
Will definitely add this to our family dinner rotation.

It is the President's responsibility to nominate a jurist to fulfill the position. It is also the Senate's responsibility to vet that nomination. This has to happen. If that candidate fails pass whatever criteria the Senate uses, then the President will have the option to cut a deal or nominate someone else. This happened 30 years ago with Robert Bork, who was completely "qualified" to be on the bench, and President Reagan was forced to nominate someone deemed to be more moderate by the Democratic-controlled Senate. This led to the unanimous confirmation of Anthony Kennedy (the long-standing swing vote on the bench).

At the time, President Reagan had around 18 months left on his second term, President Obama has 11.

This time around, both sides will likely use this nomination as a political tool in an election year, rather than as an opportunity to find middle ground.

Nowhere has more citizens under 24/7 video surveillance than the birthplace of the Magna Carta, England.  The London borough of Wandsworth alone has more police CCTV cameras  than all of Australia, a PBS documentary showed several years ago re: the Patriot Act.
Thanks.  No, the terrorists can not bring us down within our borders but they won the battle on 9/11 and have irrevocably changed our way of life.  Death by a thousand cuts.

If you can find fewer workers who are worth $15.00 an hour, you will not have to raise your prices.  What they do with their money is their business, not yours.  Getting them to give you value for what you pay them is a good part of your business, and having a negative attitude towards them is probably not an effective way to do this in a free country where they can move on.    If they are to lead decent lives, somebody sometime is going to have to straighten them out, and it looks like this task has fallen to you.

Boo is the town's gossip. His family does not participate in the usual social activities, so the town makes up stories about him. Many people fear their family and their home. Some people even walk long distances to go around another way than to go near their home.

Boo does not come out from his house, or when the neighbor's see. He was in trouble with the police when he was a young boy, and is very religious. His parents kept him inside. He lives with his brother, and Miss Stephanie claims that she saw Boo Radley stab his father in the leg while clipping out articles from the newspaper.

Scout and Jem believe that he may be the person leaving many things for them to find in the tree. They find a spelling metal, two Indian-head pennies, bars of soap that resemble Scout and Jem, a watch, gum, and some other things. When Miss Maudie's house catches on fire, Scout is outside in the cold watching. Boo comes up behind her and puts a blanket on her without Scout even noticing until she came home with a blanket around her shoulders.

Towards the end of the book, when Mr. Ewells tries to attack Jem and Scout, Boo comes out and stabbs Mr. Ewells to save Jem. Scout walks Boo home and the sheriff claims that Mr. Ewells fell on his own knife. Boo is never seen again.

Scout, at the end, "walks through" Boo's shoes when she walks him home and we realize that Scout and Jem are almost like Boo's children.

"I hope that the racist GOP obstructionism motivates a huge voter turn-out in November to defeat as many Republicans as possible."
I too! But the problem is gerrymandered districts and voter suppression. It's the digital age, where a person can make purchases online in an instant, renew licenses online, fill out every kind of form, pay bills, etc., but we have to wait in 4 hours lines to vote on decrepit machines and jump through unending hoops. Can you imagine Republicans ever winning even a local election for dog catcher if people could vote online, from anywhere, with the ease of buying from Amazon? They wouldn't. And that is why they cut up districts and suppress the vote. On day one, if Hillary or Bernie win, is to make voting as easy as ordering a pizza.
That may be so, but why are they still in control of Congress?

I hope that the racist GOP obstructionism motivates a huge voter turn-out in November to defeat as many Republicans as possible.

Perhaps the whole vile array of Republican candidates can at least serve a good purpose in the end by inspiring people to vote against them in large numbers.

Used bone-in thighs and cut them into strips, parallel to the bone, making sure to leave some meat on the bones. Cooked the bone pieces a few minutes before adding in the boneless pieces. Even in a relatively short cooked dish such as this, the bones do add flavor to the sauce.

It is not surprising, since congressmen are grossly underpaid compared to senior managers in big business.  And to want or expect them to do their best anyway is to expect them to be motivated by something other than the motives of free enterprise; this should make devotees of free enterprise nervous.  It doesnt because they are forced by the system to spend most of their time groveling for money that they are not allowed to spend on themselves.  This humiliation is a filter for congressmen, since those willing to grovel are unlikely to be hostile to free enterprise and its ways, and often not even to its excesses.

Lilou: How high did LFPR get?
Answer: just over 67% in 2000, so the current level of 62.7% is down about 4.3 percentage points.
How much of the decline in LFPR is due to increased population of retired people?
Answer: About half the decline is due to aging population, with another percentage point due to lower labor force participation from young people aged 16-25 (primarily due to increased schooling and college enrollment).

So among critical working age adults aged 25-54, the decline is about 1.6% since 2003, or a numerical decline of 1.6 million jobs from the late 1990s.

Compare this decline of 1.6 million with the +20 million jobs added during Clinton's fiscal years, the 2 million added during GWBush's fiscal years (all government jobs), and the +13 million added in the 6.3 fiscal years under Obama. Or compare the 1.6 million missing jobs you are whining about with the jobs added recently: since the beginning of 2014 we have added 5.7 million full-time private sector jobs, and are on-trend to add another 5 million over 2016-2017.

See how you have been brainwashed with propagandists using the esoteric LFPR to mislead you into believing in fake unemployment rates of 30+%? Learn something, and stop being played for a chump.

Skin on for best flavor and start cooking skin side down until skin is nicely browned. This enhances flavor greatly, even if you don't care to eat the skin after the dish is cooked. I usually drain off extra fat.

If you are selling stuff that would be purchased by people making $15 an hour but would be too expensive for people making $10, your business will take off.  At least, that was Henry Ford's experience when he did it and his fellow businessmen could not decide if he was crazy or a communist.  Of course, he was neither, but rather only a better businessman than his peers.

This kind of kabuki theater has been going on since the first supreme court.  Roosevelt threatened to increase the number of Justices to stack the court in 1937 because the Republicans had struck down a few of the New Deal measures.  Why do we have to make every decision made by the opposition the end of the of the world as we know it.  It is not about race, or the fact that our President happens to be black.  It's about the differences in the type of Justice each party wants to appoint.  Will that justice be an originalist or one that believes in the 'living document' interpretation of the constitution.

Tax cuts for the rich get sucked into financial fun and games in the grand casino in lower Manhattan.  These are not the sorts of investments that benefit anybody except the investors and their advisors.

got the missing i's with operandi and a few other obvious ones like item one and ionizing. lots of names not in my wheel house like star wars characters, but I  kept plugglung along. Did know ponti, nikolai,  gotti and adelphi. Solved on across-lite which did not make the big i's obvious. that was okay. clever puzzle.
Everyone in politics is an ideologue. It could not be otherwise.

Bernie has been an ideologue his entire career.  Most ideologues have only a passing acquaintance with reality.  Trump has been able to vault to the top of the Republican pack by speaking in vague generalities and making ridiculous economic revival claims and he has benefited greatly in the polls.  Democrats tightly mock Trump and his unrealistic followers that appear to believe his mumbo jumbo.  What amuses is that Sanders is tapping into the left wing of the Democratic Party who also display the same traits and characteristics of their right wing counterparts.

I have had several conversations with a couple of Republican Tea Party individuals.
Five minutes into the conversations the n..word was used several times. Come on is that the best you got.
Harry Truman: Respect the office if not the man.
President Obama deserves our respect. Let him do his job and move forward with a Court nominee.

Every republican act or word is turned into an "identity" charge.  Nice to see the "sexism" charge finally being debated by democrats, who are under attack for a change.  They just have to get through all the others before they realize how wrong they've been.

The GOP hasn't stopped demonizing Latinos, Muslims, gays and women who choose to exercise their reproductive rights.  Now they want to dismiss the concerns of black Americans, too?  By the time November arrives there may be no demographic left whose votes they can court.  Well, maybe rich 80-year-old white heterosexual Evangelicals.

Seems you can't make up your mind whether Sanders will be able to get nothing done or he will tank the economy by enacting his complete agenda by merely placing his hand on the Bible and taking the oath of office.

Perhaps it's more pragmatic to see these proposals as opening bargaining positions or an aspirational platform that redounds to down ballot Democrats. A platform that tells voters who is actually on their side and inviting them to set their sights a little higher.

Health care expenses are already impacting the real economy. So you don't think it can be improved? Medicare costs less than private plans despite that Medicare covers older people who need more care. Overhead savings: what is so unrealistic about demanding to pare that item at the Medicare level?

Bernie wants to wage a divisive and politically impossible fight to change the entire healthcare system a second time, all within a single decade. Hillary wants to smooth out any rough edges ObamaCare may have first, while controlling costs better with progressive ideas like changing the way we deal with drug companies. We could eventually be able add the public option first. This lets it compete and get tested, phased in over time without scaring the broader public and shocking the system. Plus, there are reasons US healthcare costs more other than efficiency. You don't want to damage the rate of technological innovation under the restrictions of a sudden and untested bureaucracy. The sheer political and ecomonimic weight of what Bernie is promising to do instantly is just too much to bear, and his numbers do not add up. Healthcare, free college and not just fixing but increasing social security all at once? That much simultaneous taxing and wealth redistribution is going to pass, really? It all going to work perfectly and not cause a massive and risky economic shock and public backlash? Progressive evolution rather that revolution has a far, far better chance of working and being accepted by a skeptical public. I'm afraid that when the true costs of Bernie's plans get a wider hearing, it will also all scare middle America even more. That my progressive friends, is a losing strategy.

Bernie seems to insist he can make up for the entire post-Reagan wealth gap increase in one false swoop of instant gratification. It's simply too much of a risk to take and would likely cause too radical an economic shockwave. Most likely an unpredictable one, that could spin the economy in a thousand different directions. Of course, this even assumes Bernie can even get himself elected and pass all of these programs in the first place. Failure of the economy during a Sanders Presidency would set back the progressive agenda fifty years. If that sounds pessimistic, it is. You won't find any apologies here. As we've all been trying to tell most Republicans for years, facts are very stubborn things.

This should be a great incentive for Dems, as if we needed any further reasons, to vote in November, to elect not only Hillary, who after a battle royal eventually will win the nomination, but to get out the vote for Democratic Senators in extremely close races ensuring at least a 50-50 divide so that Hill's VP can break any tie with her nomination of Supreme Court Justice Barack Obama.

A win-win situation that looks more appealing each day Republicans remain recalcitrant. Maybe this Democratic coup in November will be the final straw that breaks the camel's, make that elephant's, back. God knows they sure deserve a swift kick in the shins, or higher.

Dems have plenty of time. First let's see if the GOP, especially what's left of those so-called moderates. termed RINO's and traitors by Tea Party Patriots Hard Right wingnuts, who are currently acting so brave and belligerent, remain that tough through the primaries, the conventions and the General Election in the Fall. Or if in the end, after their game of "Chicken" ends in them caving, as the wimpy faction usually does, especially the closer we get to the precipice in the Fall, and those Senators in close races start perspiring that Marco Rubio sweat, when they see their polls tumble.

It's a very long road from February to November, folks, and one can be assured, this topic ain't going anywhere. In the news biz they will tell you this story's got legs, frog's legs to be exact. Let the games begin.

DD
Manhattan

Dear M.Iker: What has led us to this deep divide in American political thought has a long "corrosive" history going back decades. There is no silver bullet, panacea, that will cure all that ails US.

Sorry to say, this blood feud is going to continue to corrode, continue to do harm to this nation. The blame lies in our 24/7 media. Right Wing radio broadcasts an incessant tirade of suspicion, paranoia, conspiratorial theories on steroids. People from every corner of the country are fed this foaming-at-the-mouth fear into their homes daily. How can politicians compete with this barrage? They can't.

Old codgers like Senator Hatch had a deep affection for Ted Kennedy. Political opposites, when they could find common ground on an issue, they came together and got the legislation required passed. Those days are long gone, my friend.

As a lifelong Dem in his seventh decade on this spinning blue marble, I have seen it worse. I witnessed assassinations, of JFK, MLK, RFK, Vietnam, Watergate ( the original -Gate), Carter's malaise, Reagan's retreat after terrorists killed 250 Marines in their barracks, RR's Iran-Contra deal where this government paid ransom money for hostages, Clinton's L'Affaire Lewinski, his impeachment, Bush 43's Iraq War debacle.

And now, we are left its remnants. Hate fomenting for such a long period has metastasized into a cancer which major surgery "may" be able to cut out. Remission and Recovery are not guaranteed.

DD
Manhattan
There is nothing vain about Ginsberg, who clearly is more than capable of continuing the job, continuing to do so.

@DCBarrister
Right, because no politician has even gone back on a position; especially when defending the dubious result of guaranteeing that a SCOTUS vacancy will be unfilled for at least a year.
Far fewer voters voted for the Senate in 2014 than voted for Obama in 2012 and 2008.
